description.narrative: The Anti-corruption Programme (ACP) was approved in 2019 for a period of four years (2019-2022) and with an overall budget of DKK 100 million. The programme objectives are to enhance the effectiveness of anti-corruption efforts through strengthened cooperation, advocacy, monitoring and research in key organisations and networks at national and international level. The programme has three clusters to strengthen the role of governments, civil society and the private sector respectively with eight different partners. The design of the ACP was a response to an acknowledgment within the MFA that international cooperation and initiatives to fight corruption increasingly constitute an important supplement to anti-corruption efforts at the national level, and to help developing countries mobilise their own resources to realise the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The ACP was built around a number of existing international partnerships, but also sought to identify new ones that could generate new learning and experiences to be shared broadly. The latter include MACN, GACC and the UNCAC Coalition. Support to UNODC’s global anti-corruption efforts is also a new component that was introduced in the ACP as part of an enhanced focus on strengthening the normative anti-corruption framework.

title.narrative:
Governments and businesses live up to their key commitments in relation to UNCAC, SDG 16, EITI and other relevant anti-corruption pledges (IACC).
Targets for 2022 are: -90 % Level of compliance with Article 15 (Bribery of national public officials) of UNCAC- Will be measured by UNODC -Quality of resource governance- 10% improvement overall- see https://resourcegovernanceindex.org/ -By 2020, 25% of TI’s key advocacy goals around implementation of the IACC High Level Segment commitments; and by 2022, 50% of the key advocacy goals around implementation of the commitments have been reached/met- (commitments will be identified by TI and monitored by TI pledge tracker mechanism) -At least half of the G20 countries have central registers of beneficial ownership of companies (at least half of these are publicly available) - Will be monitored by TI’s monitoring mechanism
